title: Reynaldo Parks
text:
Reynaldo Parks Pérez (born December 4, 1974) is a retired international <a href="Costa%20Rican">Costa Rican</a> <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="defender%20%28football%29">defender</a>.
Club career.
He has played in different teams in Costa Rica, as well as in Mexico and <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>. He started out in Costa Rica with his hometown team <a href="Asociacion%20Deportiva%20Limonense">Limonense</a>, and was later transferred to <a href="C.S.%20Herediano">Herediano</a>. Then he went on to play alongside compatriot <a href="Fernando%20Patterson">Fernando Patterson</a> with <a href="C.S.D.%20Municipal">Municipal</a> in Guatemala and <a href="Jaguares%20de%20Colima">Jaguares de Colima</a> and <a href="Tecos%20UAG">Tecos UAG</a> in Mexico, before coming back to Costa Rica to play for Saprissa and <a href="CF%20Universidad%20de%20Costa%20Rica">Universidad</a>.
Parks was part of the team that played the 2005 <a href="FIFA%20Club%20World%20Championship%20Toyota%20Cup">FIFA Club World Championship Toyota Cup</a>, where <a href="Saprissa">Saprissa</a> finished third behind <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20Futebol%20Clube">São Paulo</a> and <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>.
In 2008, he moved to <a href="A.D.%20San%20Carlos">San Carlos</a> and retired in November 2009.
International career.
Parks made his debut for <a href="Costa%20Rica%20national%20football%20team">Costa Rica</a> in a February 1993 <a href="UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">UNCAF Nations Cup</a> qualification match against <a href="Nicaragua%20national%20football%20team">Nicaragua</a> and earned a total of 43 caps, scoring 1 goal. He represented his country in 15 <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">FIFA World Cup qualification</a> matches and played at the <a href="1995%20UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">1995</a> and <a href="1999%20UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">1999 UNCAF Nations Cup</a>s as well as at the <a href="1993%20CONCACAF%20Gold%20Cup">1993</a> and <a href="2002%20CONCACAF%20Gold%20Cup">2002 CONCACAF Gold Cup</a>s and the <a href="2001%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">2001 Copa América</a>. Parks was a key member of the national team that qualified for the <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a>, serving as the captain. But just before the event started, a knee injury kept him away of participating and he was replaced by <a href="Pablo%20Chinchilla">Pablo Chinchilla</a>.
His final international was an October 2003 <a href="friendly%20match">friendly match</a> against <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20football%20team">South Africa</a>.
Retirement.
After retiring, Parks became chairman of the National Costa Rica Football Players Association but resigned from his post after 7 years in January 2014.
Personal life.
Parks is married to Irma Loáiciga and they have two sons. His cousin <a href="Winston%20Parks">Winston Parks</a> also played for the Costa Rica national team.
